_prev_prog_2.Description: The TDI Process includes the unloading of TDI from tanker trucks in a contained indoor unloading bay.  The TDI is unloaded into bulk tanks stored in a separate room within the facility.  The TDI is transferred via piping to various product lines for reaction, thereby creating the foam products.  The TDI process also includes fixed air monitors and alarm system, sprinkler systems, and containment systems.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
RENOSOL SEATING, LLC
6 MEADOWCRAFT PARKWAY
SELMA, ALABAMA


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Facility
Renosol Seating, LLC endeavors in all its activities to promote a better environment. Renosol Seating, LLC recognizes that our activities have impacts on our employees and the surrounding community. It is our desire to reduce adverse impacts of our business by:

?    Continually reviewing norms and practices relative to their effect on health, safety and the environment; and
?    Taking measures to prevent pollution and injury, conserve resources, minimize waste, improve working conditions, and comply with applicable environmental laws, regulations and other requirements.

Renosol Seating, LLC is a member of the Suppliers Partnership for the Environment, a trade association comprised of automotive and vehicle suppliers who work in partnership with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  In addition, the Renosol Seating, LLC Selma, Alabama plant has been registered to ISO-14001:1996, the worldwide environmental management system standard. Renosol Seating, LLC has always taken care to ensure compliance to environmental standards and to protect the health and safety of its employees, and the ISO-14001 process provides important guidelines for continuing to examine and improve its environmental management systems. Through these and other initiatives, Renosol Seating, LLC has implemented a system that holds each employee accountable for the safety and environmental performance of the company.

The Renosol Seating, LLC Facility and the Regulated Substances Handled
The Selma, Alabama facility produces liquid polyurethane systems and polyurethane seating, headrest, armrest and console cushions for the automotive industry. Two types of foam lines are utilized at the facility?an MDI line (Methylenebis(phenylisocyanate)) and a TDI (Toluene diisocyanate) line. The other major chemical component to the

product is polyol.  Only the TDI process is subject to the RMP requirement. The TDI is transferred into two 12,000-gallon indoor storage tanks from tanker trucks. From the indoor storage tanks, TDI is transferred via hard plumbed lines to smaller retaining tanks for daily use.

The TDI foaming line consists of a multi-station race track design line with each station containing one bench seat or two bucket seat molds. At the first station, the foam (mixture of TDI and polyol) is mechanically poured into the mold. The lid to the mold is then immediately closed and clamped shut. The foam is cured as it rotates through the various stations. The lid is then opened and the foam seat is removed. The mold is vacuumed clean and a wax release agent is applied to the mold so that it can be used again.

The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The Renosol Seating, LLC Selma, Alabama Plant complies with a variety of environmental and safety programs including waste management, air emissions controls, storm water pollution prevention, spill prevention, community right-to-know programs (EPCRA), hazardous materials management, emergency response and many others. The Selma Plant is certified to the ISO14001 Standard.  Therefore, Renosol Seating, LLC has exceeded minimum efforts to comply with regulatory requirements by implementing an Environmental Management System. Central to these efforts is a consistent effort to prevent incidents and accidents, including chemical spills.

The Selma Plant is a newly-built facility constructed to the specific standards of Renosol Seating. The TDI is stored indoors within a concrete containment system constructed in an integral fashion with the building. Strict procedures are also followed when materials are unloaded including the requirement that a person observes the unloading of the delivery tanker truck.

Fixed air monitoring equipment is installed within the building to provide an early warning

of any TDI release. These monitors are inspected and tested on a regular basis to ensure their accuracy and functioning ability. The principle of detection is based on a chemical reaction caused by the presence of TDI on a chemically impregnated paper tape. A sample of plant air is drawn through the tape by a pump. When TDI is present in the sample, it causes a stain to form on the paper tape. The intensity of the stain is proportional to the concentration of TDI in the sample. A photo diode monitors the stain intensity as a chemical reaction occurs on the paper. If the intensity of the stain is above a pre-set level, the alarm relays are initiated and an indication is shown on the LCD display. The display shows flashing bells to indicate that the instrument is in alarm mode. The alarm condition persists until a reading below the alarm set point is reached. No employee is allowed back into the area until a reading of below the set alarm is reached (5 ppb is the alarm level).

The Five-Year Accident History
There have been no incidents involving TDI in the last five years. 

The Emergency Response Program
Renosol Seating, LLC has made a significant effort to communicate the elements of its response program with local emergency responders. Members of the local fire department and Local Emergency Planning Commission have visited the facility. The Corporate Health, Safety and Environmental Manager maintains his 40-hour HAZWOPER training, among other emergency response training updates and requirements. Facility personnel involved with the TDI process receive regular training on pollution prevention and emergency response. This training includes participating in an emergency drill which is documented. Alert systems are also in place at the facility. As previously described the facility is equipped with TDI air monitoring devices to provide early warning of a TDI release.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Renosol Seating, LLC continues to review its programs and procedu
res and make improvements where necessary. At this time, no significant improvement needs have been identified.
